South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are Intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid fall fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent, on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: FAST BRITISH PASSENGER STEAMERS
GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Khedivial Agricultural Society's Show
div.p: Cairo. February 13th, 1907.
J & H McLaren
Engineers, LEEDS, England,
beg to inform their friends that they propose to have a large exhibit of
Steam Ploughing Engines
Cultivators, & c., & c.
They will also exhibit their new Patent
Kassabiehs or Levelling Scoops.

Eight of these scoops were sold in Egypt last season for levelling sand or soil, and their working is "perfection." Agriculturists and Land Companies interested in reclamation or cultivation are requested to visit our stand at the show and inspect our specialities, which have been specially designed to meet the requirememnt of the Egyptian Market. Our Mr. Henry McLaren expects to arrive in Cairo about the 5th February. His address will be Shepheard's Hotel, and he will be glad to hear from anyone interested in the above classes of work.

div.head: SENOUSSI AND OTHER SOARES.
div.p: The rows published by Reuter yesterday that & powerful expedition is preparing to attack the Emir of Hadiya in the North of British Nigeria, is doubtless connected with the recent invasion of Sokoto by a band of faratios in the course of which & small British post was overwhelmed, sustaining heavy los-08 Who these fanatics 'were has not yet been revealed by the home Press, but in default of further news it seems as if the outbreak wax not isolated as far as the province is concerned, though the population and the chiefs of Sokoto appear to have loyally seconded the efforts of the British authorities to overpower the rebe's and ther Mahdi. But we greatly doubt whether the Senoussi sect had any direct connection with the movement, a contributor to the "Pall Mall Gazette," recently quoted in our columns, has inferred. The Senoussi and their leaders have always been pacific by habit and in policy. They have resisted all temptations to extend their I propaganda by the sword, and though no don't are relatively well armed have consistently avoided collisions with any of their neighbours. Sidi Mohamed Es Senousi was on on occasion summoned by the Sadanese Mahdi to join him, but the release of Kufra order his followers to observe absolute neutrality in the struggle between Egypt and the revolted Sudanese, and though his disciples were do believed to cherish the friendliest feelings towards the Ottoman Government, abstained from any conflict with the forces of the Sultan.

In our opinion it is very doubtful whether the Senoursi sect is to be regarded, under the present circumstances, as of any great political importance in N Africa. Were Tripoli and Barca to fall into the hands of a European Power and the independence of Kafra and the oases of the inner desert threatened by the pioneers of European civilisation, the procla: mation of a holy war might cause considerable disturbance in the wilder regions of N. Africa. But even in that case it is hard to see what they could affect. The invasion of Algeria, of Nigeria, or Senegal by barbarian bəsts. conquering and to conquer seems to be an idle dream. The Sahara could not support armies that must be reckoned by the hundred thousand to have the least chance of success, the resisting power of Earope even in her farthest outposts is terribly strong, and the horsemen of the desert would not have that superiority of tactics and organisation that gave victory to the hosts of Jeaghiz Khan. Because Baropean States onca fell victims to the onslaughts of the Ottoman Turks, whose civilisa. tion was in many respects superior to their own, and of the Mongols, whose leadership and military organisation have been proved by madora research to have been of the highest quality. European publicists of the present day are prone to elaborate theses on the coming conquest of the European possessions in Africa or Asia by hordes of barbarians, new Hons or Tartars. The victory of Japan is cited by the more imaginative, bat the Japanese, already the heirs of an older civilisation than our own, won their great victories and their glorious place among the nations by a brilliant display of all the highest qualities that have advanced the chief European nations to their present greatness. To conquer civilised men the bar. barian must become civilised himself, and we imagine that many generations will elapse before the dreams of those who are adopted by black, brown, yellow, or copper coloured perils are fulfilled.

div.head: EGYPTS TRADE WITH GREAT
div.p: BRITAIN. The Government Press at home, as was to be expected, is making the fullest age of the latest trade returns as an argument against a protective tariff, and exhibits ill-concealed delight at_horing placed in its hands so effectively a weapon of attack. In order to set out these returns to the best advantage, the "Westminster Gazette" has compiled, from the Sta. tistical Abstracts for the United Kingdom, an informative series of charts showing the increase of exports from Great Britain to her various foreign markets at the end of each decade since 1856 to 1904. This is prefixed by a table of the exports during the latter year, from which it appears that British India is ont largest customer, the great dependency receiving in 1904 goods to the enormous value of £40,641,000. This is fifteen-an 4-8half millions in excess of the exports to Germany, the second country in the list, and only five millions less than the combined imports of Germany and the United States, In the 49 years ander 'review India's imports were doubled, but those of Germany oily show a moderate advance, for the average annual value in million f in the years 1870 1880 is given as 99.9, and in the years 1901-1904 as 23.8, though it should be pointed out that between 1881-1890 the average bad fallen to 17.5.

Egypt is placed eleventh in the list with . total value of imports from the United Kingdom in 1904 of £8,273,00), and it is noticestle that there is only & difference of about five millions between this amount and that of the Cape, which holds fifth place, while China and Italy import respectively bat £536,000 and £98,000 more than Egypt. Russia is the smallest importer with £*,280,000.

A reference to the chart devoted to Egypt's imports reveals the fact that between 1856 and 1865 we received from the United King. dom goods to the annual value in million pounds sterling of 3.1. During the succeeding decade this rose to 6.5, but in the troubles period between 1876 and 1885 the amount fell to 2.7. Ten years later it reached a point slightly higher than 30 years previously, and continued to advance during the last nine years onder review, which had an annual value equal to 5.7. As we are aware, last year's total showed a further big increase, and 1906 gives fair promise of beating all previous records.

div.head: Cairo Opera Season Ends.
div.p: Last night the opera season at Cairo ended with Cavalleria Rusticana at the Khedivial Opera House. In the course of the week the Government will call for tenders for the concession for the exploitation of the Khedivial Opera House daring the 1906-1907 season.

div.head: "Pro-Russia."
div.p: A benefit performance of La Poupée will be given in the Ezbekieh Theatre, Cairo, op Tuesday next, by the Prenob operetta company, in aid of the Pro Rossi& Jewish Benevolent Society. The proceeds will be devoted by the latter to aiding the Jewirb emigrants from Russia.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ESTATES.
div.p: The Committee of the Stock Exchange has ordered Egyptian Estate Debentures to be quoted in the Official List and has fixed April 5 as a special settling day in these shares.

div.head: AMERICAN COAL STRIKE.
div.p: The Times' correspondent at New York states that it is not yet known whether the strike of coal miners will begin on the first of April. Representatives of the anthracite coal-owners met yesterday to consider whether they should not grant the miners their demand for a joint conference. The most hopeful feature of the situation is the evident desire of each side to avert a strike by renewing negotiations.

KABSALA RAILWAY.

div.p: Advice from Saakin shows that the Railway Department have commenced the survey of the proposed railway line to Kansala. It is hoped to make a start in laying the line for months hence.

div.head: DUKE OF CONNAUGHT AT SUEZ.
div.p: The Duke and Duchess of Connaught are expected to arrive at Saez on the 26b ipst., from East Africa, by the German steamer Prinz Regent.

div.head: ARRIVAL OF TORPEDO BOATS.
div.p: Six British torpe lo-destroyers, accompanied by H.M. 's second-class cruiser Bonaventure, arrived at Zarz last night from the South, and entered the canal this morning fór Port Said.

div.head: ARRIVAL OF AUSTRIAN FLEET.
div.p: An Austro-Hungarian squadron, under the command of Rear. Admiral de Jodina, arrived at Alexandria this morning from Corfu. The squadron consists of five yereli, four of them armoured oroi-err, each bf 8,-09 tons, and one torpedo destroyer, 400 tone. The names of the cruisers are Habsborg Appad, Babenberg, and Sanot Georg, and of the torpedo destroyer, Horzar. Their crows aggregata about 1,800 men.
The squadron, which is on a cruise in the Mediterranean, will remain in Alexandria harbour until April 11, when it will proceed to Haifa, Beirut, and Greece.
Owing to the presence of the American squadron, and the consequent crowding of the harbour, two of the cruisers anchored outside in the quarantine ground .
The Austro Hungarian Corporal and Vice Corporal paid an official visit to Rear-Admiral de Jeding this morning.
The Austro Hungarian colony of one city is preparing to fete the stay of the squadron here in a fitting manner.

div.head: IMPORTANT PROPERTY SALES IN CAIRO.
div.p: Two more property sales of importance have just been confounded in the Capital. The fir-t is that of the palace and grounds of Prince Saïd Halim, sita- ted in the Front quarter, and consisting of a very fine residence and Home 6,000 square metres of land laid out as pleasure grande. This property has been bought for £84,000 by Count Raspudi, a deputy of the Italian Parliament, through M. P. Fonti, the Cairo engineer and contractor, who acted on behalf of the purchaser. The i palace was built some five years back by Mr. Nicola Marciano at a onet of £10 000.

The other property is that belonging to M. Fortunato Tederobi, agent of the Austrian Lloyd at Heligan, in the Sharia El Madabegb, opposite the now premines which are to be built for Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi. It consists of a building of four stories containing seven large apartments, including some offices in the basement, and was sold to Messrs. 8. and G. Tahet, wh 88 recent parobase of part of the Coronel property in the Fame street for LB. 84,000 was mentioned in our 188ne of the 7th instant, The Rite of 1 200 square metres was bought by its former owner in 1888 for about £1 500 and the house cost another £6,000 80 that there was a profit of some £ 2,000 , over this transaction.

div.head: CAIRO TRAMWAYS.
div.p: The above company have now received the whole of the fifty cars of a new and improved pattern which were ordered last year in Belgium, and the first lot will be pat on the principal lines in the beginning of next month. Several were mach dam-ged during their transit from Europe, caused by the very bad weather the last steamer encountered in the Mediterranean There new cars contain a special compartment for first-class passengers, wider than thore now in one, which is placed in front dexo to the wattman, whilst a similar compartment for ladies is at the other end, the centre being reserved for the second-oland passengers.

We gave some months ago a detailed list of the goveral extensions and new lives the company were authorised at the time to add to their present system. The first two taken in band, and which are now approaching completion, are the prolongation of whát is known as the Khalig line from the terminals at Daber to Abbas avende, ending at the Gamrah bridge, and the extension of the same line in the opposite direction as far as the abattoirs. For the prolongation of iba Bonao line, now also under construction, from its present terminal point at the landing-stage of tbe Gbezireb Palace Hotel ferry to the railway workshops, it is necessary, in cops quence of the extreme Narrowness of some of the streets in that district, to construct a river embankment which is to be 150 metres in length and 20 metres wide, and was estimated to cost about £6 000.

According to the new concession granted by the Government in July last these three extenSions will have to be ready and opened to traffic in one year from that date, that is in four months from now. The other extensions and dow lines, which include the prolongation of the one on the Shoubra-road, the new Sapien line, and others, will be taken in band when the three we mentioned above are completed.

div.head:
THE SUCRERIES.
FINALLY DECLARED BANKRUPT
CONSTERNATION AND DISMAY IN COURT
div.p: With this morning's judgment in the Mixed Court of Appeal the curtain fall on the most poignant industrial tragedy which has taken place in Egypt since the collapse of the "Barque Industrielle." Up to the last it was expected that the Appeal Court would pot ophold i he judgment of the Cairo Tribunal, and an eager and expectant audience gathered at the Mixed Tribunals this morning to hear what would be the decision of the Court on one of the most momentous cases ever brought before a law. court in Egypt. At 9.15 o'clock the "disposition" of the judgment was read out by the clerk of the Court, and as soon as it was seen that the bankruptcy had been confirmed, consternation and dismay were visible on most of the countenances of the crowd.

The following is the dispositif" of the judgment: Pageant contradictoirement, le Ministère Pablio entendu, reçoit en la forme l'intervention des parties représentées par M Mes Padoa Bey et Roo8808. Au fond, soartant toutes conclusions plus amples ou contraires des parties déolare la Société Générale des Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d'Egypte mal fondée en son appel; l'en déboate; en con équence, confirme le jagement du Tribanal Mixte de Commerce da Caire en date da 24 février et 3 mars 1906 et dont appel ;- frais à charge de la masse ;-dit, epfin, que les intervenants avront à sopporter leurs pro; res frais par devant la Cour.

The following is the dispositif" of the judgment: Pageant contradictoirement, le Ministère Pablio entendu, reçoit en la forme l'intervention des parties représentées par M Mes Padoa Bey et Roo8808. Au fond, soartant toutes conclusions plus amples ou contraires des parties déolare la Société Générale des Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d'Egypte mal fondée en son appel; l'en déboate; en con équence, confirme le jagement du Tribanal Mixte de Commerce da Caire en date da 24 février et 3 mars 1906 et dont appel ;- frais à charge de la masse ;-dit, epfin, que les intervenants avront à sopporter leurs pro; res frais par devant la Cour. . It is to be noted that in one of the clauses of the judgment the judges expressed the view that what has been done before bankraptoy can also be done after, and that, instead of a "concordat preventit," the company can be reconstitated by a "ooncordat ordinaire." This would be trge in ordinary cages, but in the case of the Sucreries it is m possible as no long than one million pounds of new capital have bred subscribed in the concordat and no financier world, of course, subscribe anything after the declaration of bankruptcy.

Meanwhile the Daira Sagar Corporation will take steps to take possession of those of the factories which forms part of the assets of the late Daira Sanieh. The present board of the company or ringas to remain in charge where 88, had the concordat been sanotione 1, it would have been replaced by the eminent men whose Dames we mentioned last week.

We must sympathise with the distingai bed counsel for the various interests which are so much affected by this morning's catastrophe. Maitre Carton de Wiart has done his best to combine all the cor floating interests and to obtain some order, oat of the terrible chaos consequent on Cronier's death It must be moat paypal for bim to see all handiwork 'shattered to pieces by the judgment, for we believe we are right in saying that dirin. hiel long career at the Bar. he has never had a more difficult task.

To-morrow afternoon thera will be another meeting of the creditors of the company at the Cairo Mixed Court in continuation of that bled on Monday afternoon. At that meeting M. Sampaolo read the following report :

"D'après l'art. 280 (non vean) du Code de commerce, les syndics, en toute faillite sont tonos de remettre, dans la grinzane du jugement de déclaration de faillite &a juge-commis on mémoire de compte-rendu sommaire de l'état apparent de la faillite.

"Mais, dans le c39 présent, pone croyons être dispensé de cette formalité, puisque dans les rapports qui ont été dressés et publiés pour les experts, 80 nombre desquels nous Étions, lors de la demande de la Société en option da concordat, 2008 avons déjà exposé le résultat de l'ex-men minations et comBier cieux des livres et pièces produits, et doté notre avis."
The report afterwards dealt with the inventory made by the syndio.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Archduke Joseph and the Archduchess Augusta of Angtria arrived at Khartoum lagt Thoreday. The S.S. Abba- has been chartered for their Imperial Highpegles, who will go up the White Nile as far as Kodok, after which they will return to Khartoum and Cairo.
On the 6th proxo. the members of the Legislative Coupoil, who recently visited Port 8ndan, will give a banquet in honour of the Sirdar,
Mr. and Lady Victoria Machell are expected to arrive in Cairo on Friday next.
H. E. Saba Pacha the Postmaster-General, in leaving to-day by the German steamer for Rrme, u bore be will attend the Postal Congrega, which is to commence sitting on the 7th proxo.
Rear-Admiral Sigabee, commanding the American Equadron in Alexandria harbour, rotamead from his visit to Cairo yesterday evening.
Baroness Rocker.Jenisch is leaving Alex andria this afternoon by the North-German Lloyd steamer en route to Berlin to rejoin her husband.

div.head:
CIVIL SERVANTS INDIGNANT.
AN OBNOXIOUS CIRCULAR.
div.p: A correspondent writer :- Considerable excitement exists in official orioles in Cairo. | consequent op & cironlar expressing regret that so few members of the Civil Service subscribe to the Anglo-American Hospital. In itself there is nothing in the circular to which exception could be taken, if it were not that a list of non-subscribers hue bien sent to each head of department, coupled with the observation that if the required subscriptions are not forthcoming the hospital will have to be closed:

This method of raising money is looked upon by the Government servants as altogether unwarrantable, and considerable indignation exists among the junior members of the public services, many of whom oan ill afford to add to their bardens by subscribing to a hospital which cannot be said to have been established exclusively for them.

div.head: ITALIAN SCHOOLS IN CAIRO.
div.p: The erection of the large block of buildings which are to boost the four schools belonging to the Italian Government in Cairo was commenced this week, and they are estimated to cost about 400.000 fronos when completed. The plans and designs were prepared by Mr. T. Parvie, engineer and architect of Sharia Al Dabbagh, who was deputed by the authorities at Rome to submit & detailed project with Betimates last year.

The schools are to be built on the 6000 square metres bought some years ago for this purpose from the Egyptian Governo ent and situated on the Bolao-road, close to the Abon Ellela bridge, and will have a frontage on the Dew Abbas boulevard whose is to be made from Kasr-el-Nil to Abbasiyah. This ground was sold at P.T. 80 per square metre, which was half the estimated valas at the time of parKobase, whereas now adjacent building sites are forbing quite ten times this sum.

The premises when completed will have accommodation for the whole of the 1.000 pupils of both sexes which attend the foar schools that are now distributed in different quarters of the city. The handsome and connected buildings, which are to be erected by Mears G. Garazzi and Piglio, are to be completed by the 1st November next. One of the buildings will be set apart for & commercial and technical school and the teaching staff will involve English and French professors.

We understand that the Italian Government, allows & yearly subvention of 200,000 francs, or £4,000, to the schnols established in the different principal towns of Egypt and has given a grant besides towards the expense of konstrotting the sobolaatio establishment in Cairo.

div.head: NEW EGYPTIAN COMPANY.
div.p: Yesterday the action brought by the New Egyptian Company against the Eygptian government came on for hearing before the Cairo Mixed Tribunals. The company, among other concessions obtained from the Government, has the right of creating and ameliorating islets on the Nile. But when the company has created the iglet, the Government has claimed the right of two-thirds of the lands reclaimed from the river. The Government yesterday obtained an adjarnation of the case until the 17th proxy.

div.head: BANK OF ROUMANIA.
div.p: It is rumored that a Paris banking firm, in cooperation with a Vienna bank, is eng-ged in the transformation of the Bank of Romania, Limited, which hitherto has been almost a English institution, into a Romanian joint stock company. At the same time the bank's capital will be increased from 7,500 000f. to 15 000,000f

div.head: SOCIETE KHEDIVIAL DE GEOGR PAJE
div.p: A l'ordre da joar de la séance de ramedi présidée par 8.B. Abbate Pacha figoraient deux lectores sur Marsa Matroob et territoires ad jacents, où les auteurs ont passé plusieurs mois l'été dernier.

M. Furlan, le géologue bien connu, et décrit en détail la ligne de la côte d'Alexandrie à Marsa, sa formation, des points de refuge, on happy.nt 8a description par une belle carte à grande échelle par loi droguée et exposée dans la salle. Il a parlé op gaita des deni tribus de bédouins qui l'habitent, les Ouled Ali et les S nágra, qai prétendent, comme on le sait, descendre d'un sicilien naufragé dans ces parages I Après M. Pourtau M. Pachondaki a parlé de l'industrie spéciale des eaux de Marsa, la pêche des éponges.

Après un coup d'oeil sur cette in. dustrie et les mesures prises par plusieurs goo. événements, y compris le gouvernement égyptien (les locuteurs so rappellent la part qu'à 400 la Société dans cette mesure) pour empêcher la pêche au scaphandre, il a donné des détails intéressants sur les moeurs de ces colonies de pdc bears et sur l'organisation de la pêche, en présentant à l'assemblée de balles photographies et des échantillons des différentes qualités d'éponges.
Les deux conférences, suivies aveo la plus vive attention par l'auditoire, ont été salober par de chaledroox applaudissements.

La Secrétaire Gé, éral, al commencement de la séance, après le tare da prods-verbal et 'annonce que plusieurs institutions Foientífi. gne demandaient d'entrer en rapport avec la s cibe, a informe l'Agremblée que le C mitt Organisateurs IXème Congrès International de Géographie, qui aura lieu à Genève en 1908, a Désigné 8. E. Abbate Pacha comme Vice Président et Bonola Bey comme membre du Comité d'hornu qar.

div.head: AN INTERESTING BREED OF DOGS.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Dear Sir, I should be much obliged if any of your readers could afford me accurate information as to the origin of the very interesting breed of dogs emanating from, and named after, the village of Armant in Upper Egypt.

Such specimens as I have had ander observation from time to time seem to possess : very marked and interesting characteristics and lay fair claim, I think, to some attention from a utility point of view and also for their handsome appearance.

As watch dogs they are held in just esteem 'by the natives, especially for protecting crops and cattle, and from the age of six weeks will loodly herald the approach of any stranger. This is a characteristic of the breed and not confined to isolated specimens, as is frequently thô 0940, with English dogs nach en ball-dogs and mastiffs. Indeed the ball-dog which finds favour on the show-bench dow-s-days hardly, possesses so efficient of energy to bark if trodden apod, and the mastiff is no longer necessarily associated with strength, faithfulness', and tenacity of purpose.

I have been informed by natives that the "Armant" originated from dogs of the St. Bernard race which were brought over to this country by Napoleon's army and thereafter interbred with the "parish." This might possibly account for the breadth of skill and shape of limb and is interesting if only from & legendary point of view, though I am convinced a modern St. Bernard would soon succumb to the summer best in Upper Egypt.

The natives of the Maremma plains and the peasants of Catalonia have a special broei of dogs possessing somewhat similar characteristics to the "Armant" and these are highly prized and carefully bred in those districts.

Possibly if some of the native notables who. breed the "Armant" would form & standard of "prints," the Khedivial Agricultural Society might be induced to form a class for exhibition purposes at their songal Show, offering prizes for the best specimens and thereby fostering the breed.

There is also another distinct race of dogs in this country bred by the Bedonios and aged by them for b inting gazelle. One or two specimens would I have seen were somewhat akin to, bat more powerful than the English greyhound.
Yours faithfully,

div.head: NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT.
CONVERSION TO STATE BANK.
div.p: The changes involved by the death of Bir Eiwin Palmer, says the "Economist," are not confined to the succession of a new Governor, but are likely to develop into several radical alterations affecting the very constitution of the National Bank of Egypt, with a corres. ponding reaction upon the financial situation of Egypt and its relations with the money markets of the world. Or, perhaps, it would be correct to say that these alterations form the organic evolution inevitably necessary if the Bapk is to fulfil its dataral functions. As is opportapely observed by a sound oritio in Egypt, the National Bank in the ten years it now counts of existence has a bad little that is national in its functions save the name. It is trao that it enjoys the privilege of a banknote issue, which is beginning to attain a oreditable circulation even among the native population, amounting now to about one million sterling. Furthermore, it enjoys in & special degree the confidence of the Government, which, from the moment the Anglo-French accord liberated its finances from international supervision, made the National Bank its banker for the deposit of funds and the service of the Treasury. Bat that so far, is all. While the Bank's connection with the Government administrations, and its affiliations, so to speak, with the Agricultural Bank, and, in a minor degree, with the Bank of Abyssinia, invest it with a status which otherwise it would not possess, the role of the Bank in the financial and commercial world of Egypt itself is in reality of less considerable divergence than that of the Crédit Lyonnais, which occupies in many respects a preponderant situation in this country. It is, in the first place, the treasurer of the Caisse de la Dette, still the second great Exchequer of Egypt; and 8: a deposit bank par excellence, with an extensive business in parel booking, which has been the strength of this institution. The Crédit Lyonnais has regulated the money market of Egypt to an extent hitherto beyond the power of the National Bank. The position, in other words, is this : If the Bank can count on the Stato, the State cannot count in an equal degree on the Bank. The policy of the latter has been that of an ordinary joint stock institution : to gain the utmost adafruit possible of the faņds in its custody; and, therefore, should a crisis ever unhappily 'arise, it would be useless for the State, or for other banka, to seek for aid from the anomslogolynamed National Bank, since the latter might be similarly involved in the orisie, and stand itself in need of susistancə to sustain its credit.

While the large reserve funds bequeathed by the Caisse de la Dette existed. and 80 long as it lasts, the need of building apa central metallic reserve was a matter of some remoteness; but the gradual exhaustion of this substantial legacy lens argonay to the question. The authority from whom I have quoted affirms that the process of transforming the National Bank into a State Bank, on the pattern of the Bank of England, the Bank of France, and the other national institutions of Europe, has made perceptible progress within the past month, and that a definite solution is not far distant. It is tolerably certain that the powers of the Governor of the Bank will be diminished, and those of the Board and the Government delegate increased, The Caisse de la Dette bas bad many detractors, bat it cannot be denied that it stood as the symbol of sound Egyptian credit, and to-day the Government to profiting by the wealth accumulated under its vigilance, As the Caisse is now, however, travelling on the road to extinction, the void has to be filled. The enormous effilox of wealth to Egypt, and the disarray of the London money market last year--to which Egypt's requirements power. fully contributed - are among the many cogent reasons for the establishment of Egyptiap finances on a basis of independent stability.

Le groupe des Hôtels est resté relativement calme. Les Nangovich ont coloré à 17.9/16. les Baehler à 6 et les Upper Egypt á 5 1/2.

Dans le compartiment des petites vallegre, nombreages transactions on Glymenopoulo, qoi ont clotoré à 1 9/16. Les Ably ont également abcès & 1 3/8. Lo Now Beyptian ont fi.id 36 sh. 6, et les Hooker à 16/32, Los Delta Land sont revenus á 3 8/8.

On rapporte de bonne source que la création de £2,000,000 d'obligations nouvelles, décidés il y a quelque temps par l'Agricultural Bank of Egypt, serait anjoard'hui une affaire définitivement conclue. 1. Ces obligations, dont l'émission apre lien incessamment, porteraient le même intérêt que los précédentes, soit 8 1/2 pour cent, mais elles seraient d'un type nouveau, on CO BODA qu'elles diraient de la garantie directe du gouvernement, ce qui en assurerait le placement au pair.
C'est à cette nouvelle, encore peu connue, I qu'il faudrait attribuer le mouvement qui s'est dessiné ce matin pour l'Agricole, mouvement que l'on croit appelé à s'accentuer.
Saient des informations de Brazeilles, lo dividende de la Compagnie immobilière dE skype sera, cette année, de 18 à 20 franos pour l'action de capital.
Extrait d'une correspondance de Londres, on date du 13 mars, sur la situation monétaire:

"A la Banane d'Anglaterra le- entrées d'or ont excédé les sorties de £ 735,000 et la proportion de la réserve aux engagements & passé de 48. 13 à 46 98 C'est par prudence que les directeurs maintiennent à 4 % le taux officiel de l'escompte qui, l'année dernière à la même époque, était à 2 1/2 pour cent.

"Le bilan de la Banque de France accare, d'autre part, en fort excès de disponibilités, et le taux d'escompte de 3 %, immuable pour certaines raisons, pourrait être sans inconvénient abaissé à 2 1/2 ou 2 pour cent."

"Sommo tonte, l'abondance et la facilité de l'argent sont plus grandes que jamais sör les mariés régulatoire, ce qui explique les dispositions à la banque. Il est certain que la Banque d'Angleterre será contrainte de réduire le taya minimum officiel après l'échéance de mars, a moins que d'ici là la tension monétaire allemande prône de la gravité par suite d'ingi. dents de la politique générale et à moins encore que l'état précaire de la Bourse, de New York so mae en crise."

div.head: KAZANTZI CONCERT.
div.p: Judging from outward and visible signs, floral invites, wreaths of laurel and so forth. M. and Milo Kaanizi scored a marvelon and spontaneous success on Monday afternoon at the Savoy Hotel. From & perhaps ultra oritical and exigeante view these arii.tes would have shown 10 grenier advantage in they bad appeared earlier in the beasin, and before Siguor Serato and M. Palli Kuculusky badly imbued their audience with a big believer in their various poword. There 18.mach to admire in M. Kazalizio, playing, his technique is carelui, be bas & bense of restraint and quiet feeling that are all in his favour,and it is very unfair to judge him by the standards already mentioned. His second item, Bach's "Aria," WEB & great improvement on his first, Mon delssohu's "Concerto en mi," which was in Du way convincing, and Wiedlapoki's Scbbi 20 Tarentello" was received with very fair av. plause. He also received various bouquets of flowers atter his rendering of the "Caprice by Paganiui, though from & personal point of view he scored the snccells of the afternoon in his sendering of the Souvenir de Museo" by Wieniawki, the central theme of which form the melody of that delightful adaptation "I will wear Do red Baraful, mother coast your weeping.

As is often the case, Mlle Kozantai is a better pianist than she is accompanist. Her playing way too obvious and at times was inclined to overheat on the subtleties of the violin. div.head: ARAB SIEGE OF SANA.
ENGLISHMAN'S GRUESOME STORY
div.p: An Englishman, Mr. Leland Buxton, who has recently arrived in London, after a tour in the Persian Gulf and in Yemen, relator & remarkable story of the state of things existing at Sana.

"We found Sana," he stated ip an interview. "to be practically depopulated, having been reduced from & population of 70,000 to something like 20,000 88 & regnlt of the famine during the Arab siege. The Jows suffered terribly during this period, and almost the whole town is deserted. Sana, which, so far as I know, has only been visited by a few English men, has magnificent and very large buildings, louvered with decorations, and the town is surrounded by mud walls. There was a very large number of Turkish troops in the town when I was there. It was stated that the Imam was driven to rebellion against the Tarks by the local sheikhs."

Mr. Buxton stated that on his way to the capital he found villages had been destroyed by the Turkish artillery, and that a great portion of the route to Sana was entirely depopulated. Large numbers of skeletons and skulls marked the route.

The siege of Suna was attended by terrible suffering and starvation, and cannibalism occurred buth among the Arabs and the Turks. The people were reduced to terrible straits. and one Tark bimrolf admitted that he had killed and eaten thres Arabs. The dogs, which are a characteristic feature of most Eastern towns, had disappeared, both they and the cats having been used as food. The only European Dans is an Italian trader, who was in the place throughout the siegs, and who has lived there for 20 years.
While in Bagdad Mr. Buxton specially made inquiries as to what extent British commerce was being affected by German trade, but found out the former was still holding its own.

div.head: REGISTRY OFFICES IN EGYPT.
div.p: Among the questions dealt with in the Judicial Adviser s Report is that of the imperawoly urgent character of the proposed decentralisation of ihe Registry Offices. As is well known, there are only three offices where registration can be fitted at present, v 2., at the Tribunals of Cairo, Alexandria, and Mansourah, it will leave aside the Mebkemehs, where low registrations are offered.

The most cursory glance, saye the Auviser, at the countant increase in the number of deeds to which pabudity is given an increase which has been enormous during the last few years, especially at the Cairo Tribunal – is, I should think, Bufficient tu conviude anybody that the present building can scarce y last moob longer without the gravest danger tu the severity of titles to real property. The proposal submitted to be Puwero, providing for the creation of a number of Registry Offices in the provicor, wuala do a Way wib tbo about overcrowding, which is 80 prejudicial to the effect rency uf au administration in which executes and precision are absolutely indispensable. And the Government could effectively supervise the working of such an administration, once the Registries were no longer concentrated at the seats of Tribunals.

In these circumstances, it is more than ever desirable that an agreement should be arrived at Without further delay, and that the propos. ed reform, which is clearly quite as mood is the interest of foreigners as of natives, should speedily be affected.

div.head: EXPORTS OF COTTON IN FEBRUARY
div.p: The export- of cotton yarn from Great Britain in February, according to the Board of Trade returns, were again on a large scale, making the aggregate weight 80 far this year almost a record amount. A feature is the Largely increased takings of Romania. Then our cotton piece goods shipments for the last to months are decidedly heavier than in 1905, and our exports of textile machinery are on a moi b freer scalo this year as compared with 1905. Employment in Lancashire in spinning and weaving was never -80 tall; indeed, operative weavers are the source, looms being idle for want of hands being reporter from the district of Blackburn. All skilled labour is working full hours, and in some Cerer overtime is being run.

With the object of stimulating public interest i 18) albire in 1b work of the British Cotton-Growing Association, and obtaining official county support on behalf of the movement, & p.ivato conference was beld a few days ago at Liverpool Town Hall between representatives of County Palatino and the Cotton-Growing Association. The company present included the Lord-Lien tenant (Earl Derby), the Lord Mayors of Liverpool and Manchester, being High Sheriff of Lanra. shire (Sir John Thorsby), the High Sheriff eipot (Mr. T. Broudhor.ty and Sir Alfred Jones (president of the Cotton-Growing A8A0ciation), Important development to anticipate od from this influential co-operation.

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICIAIRE
COUR D'APPEL MIXTE.
L'affaire du Mona House.
(ARRÊT RENDU PAR LA 2ME CHAMBRE)
div.p: Attenda que les appelants prétendent qu'en l'espèce n'existerait ancon des cas de préemption déterminés par 1x loi (art. 1 n° 2 du décret du 26 mars 1900).

Que préalablement à cette exception, fondée sur des textes légaux, ils invoquent encore deux moyens d'irrecevabilité ; le premier tiré du fait qu'en l'espèce l'objet de la vente de serait pas à proprement parler un simple immeuble, mais on tonds industriel, comprenant des éléments don sujets à préemption (ac galandage, non mobilier...); le second, tiré du mobile purement spéculatif poursuivi par les préempteurs, lesquels obercheraient à s'enrichir aux dépens d'autrui, alors que la préemption serait établie pour l'utilité réciproque des héritiers platos que pour le profit personnel des voisine.

Attendu que s'il appartient et s'il incombe au pouvoir judiciaire de se conformer aux principes du droit paternel et de l'équité en 088 de silence, d'insuffisance et d'obscurité de la loi (Regt. d'Org. Judiciaire art. 34 et 0. 0. art. 11), il ne lui appartient pas de stator par voie de dispositions générales dans les matières législativement réglementées, et ce, en créant par voie de jurisprudence des distinctions, des exclusions ou des fins de non recevoir que la loi n'a pas prévues;
Qu'en l'espèce les deux cas de non recevoir sont dono inadmissibles, par os seul motif qu'elles ne s'appuient sur saôn texte légal.

Que l'on pourrait, à la vérité, concevoir un système législatif qui laisserait au juge la faculté d'apprécier en fait si la préemų tion justifie. d'un intérêt exceptionnel à l'acquisitión de l'immeuble préempté, tel que celui qui existe manifestement dans le cas prévu par le n° 2 8 2 de l'art. 1 da décret sur la préemption on dans des cas analogues, c'est à-dire lorsqu'il s'agit d'arriver à l'extinction par voie de confusion de servitudes existantes ou simplement de prévenir des incommodisés à paître d'an Dosso rapport de voisinage; mais les conditions d'admissibilité de la préemption étant établies par la loi, et ce, en des termes impératifs, qui ne laissent au juge 8000n pouvoir d'appréciation en dehors (bien entendu) de sa faculté naturelle d'interpréter les dispositions légales, il va de soi que le juge ne peut rejeter la préemption pour des considérations ultra-légales, quelque rationnelles on équitables qu'elles puissent lai paraître.

Attendu qu'en l'espècs l'appelant invoque, d'ailleurs vainement, l'esprit général de la législation ; que, tout d'abord, il argue à tort de prétendre mobile spéculatif de la préemption litigieuse ; car toate préemption constitue Ons spéculation, et il est impossible d'en concevoir une qui ne constituerait pas un avantage pour le fonds de préemption, en même temps qu'une utilité personnelle pour le préempteur lui-même ; en sorte que la fin de non recevoir tirée d'un prétendu mobile spé. relatif revient en somme à faire un procès à la loi ;

Qae vainement l'appelant a encore argae da fait qu'en l'espèce l'immeuble préempté constituerait un fonds industriel, alors que la loi autorise la préemption de toutes espèces de fonds (terrains ou constructions), pourvu qu'il s'agisse de fonds tenus en pleine propriété, soit par le préempteur, soit par le préempté. Que L'appelant n'a d'ailleurs pas expliqué pourquoi les fonds industriels devraient échapper à la loi commune et ne pourraient pas être préemp. tés, quoique susceptibles de servir de base à une préemption, ni pour quels motifs il conviendrait de faire en la matière des distinctions individuelles en créant ale sorte de privilège en faveur de certaines catégories d'individus.

Qu'on ne voit pas, par exemple, (à ne considérer que l'espèce actuelle), pourquoi l'établissement connu sous le nom de "Mens House" ancienne propriété des époux Locke-King ne pourrait être exploité par les préempteurs actuels, les époux Rikki, par voie de location on autrement, au même titre qu'il l'était jadis par les époux Looke-King, ni pourquoi one prêté. rence devrait être accordée à un professionnel de l'hôtellerie, ou à une société anonyme;

Que vainement le consolant argae enfin de ce que dans les fonds industriels l'objet de la vente ne serait pas un simple immeuble, mais comprendrait, en outre, un achalandage et on mobilier, éléments donc sujets à préemption ; qu'à bon droit les premiers juges ont tenu ces éléments comme des accessoires destinés à goi. vre le sort du principal, mais c'est bien à tort qu'ils ont en même temps tranché une question a non soulevés par les parties, en supposant une prétendue faculté de requérir ope distraction des meubles, soit de la part da préempteur, soit de la part da préempté ; ce qui est en contradiction patente avec les premiers d'âne thèse consistant à considérer le mobilier com. pris dans la vente d'un hôtel comme on accès. goire de l'immeuble. Que la vérité est que le droit de préemption est indivisible (Kadry Patch, statut réel, d'après le rite Hanafite, art. 135 N° 1); d'où la conséquence formellement prévue par le texte précité: "Que nul ne peut " acquérir par préemption one partie d'un "immeuble vendu, en laissant l'autre partie à " l'acheteur"; d'où encore, la conséquence don moins logique, que le préempteur ne peut conquérir le fonds préempté sans sus accessoires naturels on industriels, à moins que la distraction ne soit acceptée par le préempté;
Attendu que la véritable question litigieuse est donc de savoir si la préemption actuelle rentre dans l'un des cas prévus par l'art. 1 N° 2 du décret sur la préemption du 26 mars 1900. (à suivre)

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
(Aujourd'hui à midi et demis)
div.p: La faillite des Sucreries, confirmée. ce matin par la Cour d'Appel Mixte, & produit sur notre marché en effet déprimant.
La plupart des valeurs accusent une réso. tion plus ou moins sensible, excepté l'Agricole, la Rameb Railway et la Delta Light, sar les. quelles en mouvement à la ba 0880 880 imminent.
Quant aux Sucreries, elles sont offertes à | 13 frados. Ce désastre n'a d'égal que celui de l'Industrielle.
Voici le cours des valeurs qui ont été le plat en faveur ces jours derniers : Casas di Sconto 219, Comptoir 6 7/8, Estates 2, Dalta Land 8 7/16, Urbine 6 1/4.
Pour les autres on n'a qu'à consulter la cote officielle.

La Land Allotment est momentanément dé. laissés à des prix très avantageux, 4 l'action et 160 la part de fondateur. Il va sans dire que ces cours sont paremont nominaux et que la plas patito demande ferait immédiatement hangsen les prix. | Les recettes de la Ramleh Railway da 11 81 17 mars 1905 RE Bont élevées s L.E. 915 contre L.E. 692 en 1905. Ces prix indiquent une plus valdo de près de 40 % en faveur de l'année courante. div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

Medical, antiseptic, used and recommended by eminent dermatoligists in the treatment of ecsema, lepers, psoriasis, ulcerations, skin eruptions, itching and irritating skin humours, baby rashes, etc., also a prophylactic against the risk of contracting disease and infectionus disorders generally. Its healing properties greatly minimize the inconveniences of shaving in cases of pimples, spots, In Tablets price 1/- sold by Max Fischer Alexandria.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
